questions.text: Most common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The image provided is an endoscopic view of the nasopharynx. The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller, which is located posterior to the torus tubarius. The torus tubarius is an elevation formed by the cartilaginous portion of the Eustachian tube, and the fossa of Rosenmüller is the recess behind this elevation. Site number 2 in the image corresponds to the fossa of Rosenmüller, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: This represents the posterior pharyngeal wall, which is not the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Option C. 3: This represents another area of the nasopharynx but is not the typical site for the origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Option D. 4: This represents the opening of the Eustachian tube. While nasopharyngeal carcinoma can affect this area, it is not the most common primary site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller, located posterior to the torus tubarius in the nasopharynx.

questions.text: A patient presented with the X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Miliary TB

 

Miliary tuberculosis (TB) is characterized by the presence of numerous small nodules that are uniformly distributed throughout the lungs. These nodules are millet-seed-sized, giving a "miliary" appearance on the chest X-ray. The image provided shows these numerous tiny nodules distributed evenly across both lung fields, which is classic for miliary TB.

 

Miliary TB occurs when a large number of Mycobacterium tuberculosis organisms disseminate through the bloodstream and lodge in multiple organs, most commonly the lungs. The small size and uniformity of the nodules in the X-ray are key diagnostic features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchogenic carcinoma: This typically presents as a mass lesion on an X-ray, which may cause collapse of the surrounding lung tissue. The absence of a clear mass lesion on the X-ray rules out bronchogenic carcinoma as the most likely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Aspergilloma: Aspergilloma is characterized by the presence of a fungal ball within a pre-existing lung cavity. On an X-ray, this would appear as a cavity with a round or oval density within it, often surrounded by an air crescent, known as the "monad sign" or "air crescent sign."

 

 

Option C. Lung abscess: A lung abscess is typically seen as a cavity with an air-fluid level, where the top of the cavity shows air and the bottom contains fluid. The X-ray provided does not show such a cavity with an air-fluid level, making this option less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Miliary TB presents with numerous small, uniformly distributed nodules on a chest X-ray, resembling millet seeds. This pattern is a hallmark of disseminated tuberculosis.

choices.text: Family is not satisfied with police

questions.text: In which condition both police and magistrate can do the inquest, but magistrate inquest will be preferred? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Family is not satisfied with police

 

Explanation:

 

An inquest is a legal investigation into the cause of death. In India, inquests are generally conducted under BNSS (formerly CrPC). Two types of inquests exist:

 

  1. Police Inquest (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC):
    • Conducted by the police officer (minimum rank: Head Constable).
    • Most commonly used in cases of unnatural death (e.g., accidents, suicides, homicides).
  2. Magistrate Inquest (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC):
    • Conducted by an Executive or Judicial Magistrate.
    • Mandatory in special cases such as:
      • Dowry Deaths
      • Custodial Deaths
      • Exhumation (digging out a buried body)
      • However, apart from above, in any case where usually the inquest is done by police, if a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g.  family requests a magistrate-led inquest), the magistrate can do additional inquest 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death in police custody: Incorrect

 

  • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC).

  • Police cannot conduct an inquest in custodial deaths

    ​

Option C. Dowry death: Incorrect

 

  • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC).
  • Dowry deaths must be investigated by a Magistrate, not the police

 

Option D. Death by firing: Incorrect

 

  • Only a Police inquest is done (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC).
  • A Magistrate inquest is not mandatory in cases of death by firing​

     

Educational Objective:

 

If the family is not satisfied with a police inquest, they can appeal for a Magistrate inquest, which will be preferred to ensure justice. However, custodial deaths and dowry deaths require mandatory Magistrate inquests, while deaths by firing are handled by police inquests​

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. DC shock

 

The patient presents with symptoms of palpitations and dizziness and is found to have an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG, consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The absence of distinct P waves and the presence of fibrillatory waves further support this diagnosis.

 

The patient's vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 84/46 mm Hg, indicating hemodynamic instability. In cases of tachyarrhythmias such as AF, the management approach depends on the patient's hemodynamic status. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable, immediate intervention is required.

 

Synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with AF. This procedure involves delivering a synchronized shock to restore normal rhythm. The shock is timed (synchronized) to occur at the peak of the R wave to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Specific contraindications for using synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion (synchronized DC shocking) are sinus tachycardia, multifocal atrial tachycardia digoxin toxicity. But in cases where a patient is unstable and experiencing shock, immediate cardioversion is necessary despite these contraindications, underscoring the urgency in treating life-threatening arrhythmias in acute settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent thromboembolic events in patients with AF. However, it is not the immediate intervention of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients. The priority in such cases is to stabilize the patient's condition, which requires electrical cardioversion.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used to control the heart rate in AF. They are not appropriate for initial management in an unstable patient, as they do not address the immediate need to restore a stable rhythm.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of AF. However, it is typically used in stable patients or after electrical cardioversion has been attempted. In an unstable patient, immediate electrical cardioversion is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leaves of broad ligament

 

Explanation:

 

Leaves of broad ligament:

 

  • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men.
  • In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy.
  • As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include:
    • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni: Located lateral to the fallopian tube.
    • Koblet’s tubules: Found in the outer part of the broad ligament.
    • Epoophoron: Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube.
    • Para-oophoron: Situated between the ovary and the uterus.
    • Gartner’s duct: Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pouch of Douglas: This is the rectouterine pouch, a space between the uterus and the rectum, and is not associated with remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Option C. Uterovesical pouch: This is the space between the uterus and the bladder and does not contain Wolffian duct remnants.

 

Option D. Iliac fossa: This is an anatomical region of the pelvis, and it is not related to the remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The remnants of the Wolffian ducts in females are found in the leaves of the broad ligament and the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic was admitted to the hospital for 2 days. On the 3rd day, the doctor noted agitation, confusion, disorientation, hallucination, hypertension, and sweating. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Delirium tremens

 

Delirium tremens (DT) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that usually occurs 2 to 3 days after the last drink. It is characterized by agitation, confusion, disorientation, hallucinations, hypertension, and sweating. The symptoms described in the question match those of DT, which is a medical emergency requiring immediate treatment.

 

Note -

 

Timeline of symptoms associated with withdrawal in a chronic alcoholic:

 

  • Tremors: Occur within 6-8 hours after the last drink.
  • Hallucinations: Appear around 12 hours post-drinking.
  • Seizures: Occur between 12-48 hours after the last alcohol consumption.
  • Delirium Tremens: Develops within 2-3 days after the last drink.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke's encephalopathy: This condition is caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1) and is characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. It does not typically present as acutely as described and does not fit the timeline of 2-3 days after alcohol withdrawal.

 

Option B. Korsakoff's psychosis: This is a chronic condition often following Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by severe memory impairment and confabulation. It does not present acutely within a few days of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Option C. Magnan's symptoms: These symptoms are associated with cocaine intoxication and include tactile hallucinations such as the sensation of insects crawling on or under the skin. This does not fit the description of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs 2 to 3 days after the last drink and includes symptoms like agitation, confusion, hallucinations, hypertension, and sweating.

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contrast enhanced CT scan

 

  • The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a fall is suggestive of blunt renal trauma.
  • Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross hematuria, shock in combination with microscopic hematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.
  • A CECT is the investigation of choice for blunt renal trauma in a hemodynamically stable patient.
  • Contrast enhanced CT scan (CECT):  Correct. In cases of trauma, especially from a fall, a CECT scan provides detailed imaging of the abdomen, allowing the visualization of internal organs, blood vessels, and tissues. When there's a suspicion of renal trauma due to tenderness in the left lumbar region (location of the kidney), CECT can identify the presence and extent of the injury. In a hemodynamically stable patient (as indicated by the child's stable vital signs), CECT is the preferred diagnostic modality for blunt renal trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is a radiographic study of the posterior urethra using a contrast agent. It's primarily used when there's a suspicion of urethral injury, typically indicated by symptoms like blood at the urethral meatus or an inability to urinate.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach implies observation without immediate intervention or imaging. While "wait and watch" can be appropriate in some cases, the potential seriousness of blunt renal trauma (especially in a child) warrants a more proactive approach to accurately diagnose and manage the injury.

 

Option D. Emergency laparotomy: It's indicated in situations where there's significant internal injury, and immediate surgical intervention is required. While it's a possibility in cases of trauma, the child's stable vital signs suggest a more conservative diagnostic approach, like a CECT scan, should be performed first to determine the extent of injury before jumping to surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Septate uterus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.
  • A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts
  • On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is <75, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question)
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is >105, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus
  • However, an HSG is not the ideal ix of choice
  • An MRI is the best Ix for Mullerian anomalies

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine didelphys: Uterine didelphys appears as 2 completely separate uterine cavities on the HSG with no communication whatsoever

 

 

Option C. Bicornuate uterus: Bicornuate uterus: This appears as 2 horns of the uterus which are widely separated (angle > 105 degree)

 

 

Option D. Unicornuate uterus: Unicornuate uterus: Single horn on the HSG

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anomaly seen in the image is a septate uterus which is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts.

 

Ref: Page 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6th edition

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the ER with complaints of melena. The child had intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following was found. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meckel’s diverticulum

 

Explanation:

 

Meckel’s Diverticulum:

 

  • Congenital anomaly resulting from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct.
  • Rule of 2’s:
    • Found in 2% of the population.
    • 2 feet from the ileocecal valve.
    • 2 inches long.
    • 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic).
    • 2:1 male predominance.
  • Complications:
    • Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena) due to acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa, leading to ulceration.
    • Intestinal obstruction (due to volvulus or intussusception).

    • Diverticulitis, mimicking appendicitis.

       

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructed Bowel Loops → Incorrect

 

  • Would present with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and absent bowel sounds.
  • No mention of melena or ectopic gastric tissue.

 

Option C. Appendicitis → Incorrect

 

  • While pain is in the right iliac fossa, melena is not a feature of appendicitis.
  • Would present with fever, localized tenderness, rebound tenderness, and leukocytosis.

 

Option D. Appendicular Mucocele → Incorrect

 

  • A mucocele is a mucus-filled dilatation of the appendix, usually seen in adults.
  • Presents as a mass in the right iliac fossa, but not with melena.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It presents with painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding due to ectopic gastric mucosa, mimicking appendicitis. Diagnosis is confirmed by Meckel’s scan, and treatment is surgical resection in symptomatic cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is earliest to rise in myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ischemia modified albumin

 

Explanation:

 

In the event of a myocardial infarction, certain biomarkers are released into the bloodstream as a result of cardiac muscle injury.

 

Among the three early markers of myocardial injury, three are particularly significant: myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA). Of these three, ischemia modified albumin is the earliest to rise and also the earliest to fall in response to myocardial ischemia. This rapid change makes it a valuable early diagnostic marker for detecting myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Troponin: Troponins are highly specific markers for myocardial injury and are considered the gold standard for diagnosing myocardial infarction. However, they do not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. Typically, troponin levels start to rise 4-6 hours after the onset of myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in almost all body tissues and is not specific to cardiac tissue. It is a later marker of myocardial infarction, usually rising within 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms.

 

Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB): CK-MB is a specific isoenzyme found in heart muscle and is used as a marker for myocardial infarction. However, it does not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. CK-MB levels typically start to increase 3-6 hours after myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemia modified albumin is the earliest biomarker to rise in the event of a myocardial infarction, making it a crucial early indicator for diagnosis.

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.text: A man from Chhattisgarh presented with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms in his legs. Upon examination, he exhibited a specific loss of motor function. What inquiries should be made to gather the most relevant medical history from this patient? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) History of diet

 

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may have neurolathyrism, which is caused by the excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal.
  • To confirm the diagnosis, it is important to obtain the patient's dietary history.
  • Neurolathyrism is a paralytic condition caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal, which is common in certain regions of India such as Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and Bihar.
  • The disease mainly affects the nervous system, causing gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It primarily affects males between the ages of 15 and 45 years and progresses through several stages.
  • The toxin responsible for the disease is BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine), which is water-soluble and can be removed from the pulses by soaking them in hot water and discarding the water.
  • Large-scale detoxification can be achieved by parboiling the crop, or by overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling.
  • Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can help prevent and treat lathyrism.
  • In India, the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act prohibits the use of Lathyrus sativus in any form (whole/split/flour).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SVC - Superior Vena Cava: The structure marked as A is identified as the superior vena cava, which is located on the right side of the chest

 

Option B. Aorta: The structure labeled as B is the arch of the aorta, which appears as a large circular structure in the middle of the chest.

 

Option C. Trachea: The air-filled black structure identified as C is the trachea, which appears as a circular, air-filled structure in the middle of the chest on a CT scan.

 

Option D. Esophagus: The structure marked D is the esophagus, which lies posterior to the trachea and appears as a smaller circular structure on the scan.

 

The correct matching based on the image is option B: A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When identifying structures on a chest CT, it's crucial to accurately recognize the anatomical positions of key structures like the superior vena cava, aorta, trachea, and esophagus based on their appearance and location in cross-sectional imaging.

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tay Sach’s disease

 

This is the correct answer. Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by cherry red spots on the retina, which are a distinctive sign of the condition. It is also associated with mental retardation and neurological symptoms. Tay-Sachs is a rare genetic disorder that affects the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher's Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a typical feature of Gaucher's disease. Gaucher's disease primarily affects the spleen, liver, and bone marrow, leading to symptoms such as anemia, enlarged liver and spleen, and bone pain.

 

Option C. Hunter Syndrome: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a common feature of Hunter syndrome. Hunter syndrome primarily affects connective tissues and leads to symptoms such as joint stiffness and organ enlargement.

 

Option D. Krabbe’s Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not typically seen in Krabbe disease. Krabbe disease is a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and leads to symptoms like muscle weakness and developmental delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Tay-Sachs disease is the presence of "cherry red spots" on the retina of the eye. These spots are a distinctive sign observed during eye examinations. Additionally, individuals with Tay-Sachs disease often experience progressive neurological deterioration, including muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures. There is also a characteristic decline in cognitive function, leading to intellectual and developmental disability.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X ray is shown below. What is the most likely sign and diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Snowman sign, Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Explanation:

 

The given X-ray shows a case of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC) with figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance.

 

TAPVC:

 

  • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation.
  • It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.

 

The following types are seen:

 

I. Supra cardiac – Most common type

II. Cardiac

III. Infra cardiac – Most common type for obstruction (worst prognosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus: Truncus arteriosus involves a single arterial trunk coming from the heart, not typically showing a snowman sign.

 

Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): This condition typically shows an "egg on a string" appearance due to the abnormal positioning of the great arteries.

 

Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): Characterized by a boot-shaped heart on X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy; not the pattern observed in this image.'

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "snowman sign" on a chest X-ray in a child presenting with cyanosis and fatigue is highly suggestive of Supracardiac TAPVC.

questions.text: A farmer suffered from a subcutaneous wound on the dorsum of the foot which later involved the subcutaneous tissue and produced a discharging ulcer. Microscopic examination of the discharge showed gram-positive filamentous rods with branching. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia

 

 

The patient's condition suggests a subcutaneous infection that has progressed to involve deeper tissues, leading to a discharging ulcer. The key diagnostic clue here is the microscopic finding of gram-positive filamentous rods with branching, which is characteristic of Nocardia. Nocardia is a type of actinomycete, a group of gram-positive bacteria known for their branching filamentous structure. This presentation is consistent with actinomycetoma, a type of mycetoma caused by bacteria, as opposed to eumycetoma, which is caused by fungi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Candida is a yeast, not a gram-positive filamentous rod. It typically presents as budding yeasts and pseudohyphae rather than branching rods, making it an incorrect option for this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Sporotrichosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, which presents with ulcerative lesions along lymphatic channels. It does not appear as gram-positive filamentous rods, making it inconsistent with the given microscopic findings.

 

Option C. Histoplasma: Histoplasma is a dimorphic fungus that appears as intracellular yeast forms within macrophages. It does not have the filamentous, branching rod structure observed in this case, eliminating it as a possible answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases involving subcutaneous infections with gram-positive filamentous rods and branching, consider Nocardia as the responsible organism, particularly in the context of actinomycetoma.

questions.text: Where chemical waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Yellow

 

Chemical waste is disposed of in yellow-colored containers.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Raised JVP with normal waveform

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the JVP finding? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absent a wave

 

The patient presents with an irregularly irregular pulse, which is highly suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of coordinated atrial contractions, leading to an irregularly irregular ventricular response. This irregularity can be confirmed by a pulse deficit, where the heart rate (as measured by auscultation) is higher than the pulse rate (as felt at the periphery).

 

In atrial fibrillation, the chaotic atrial activity results in the absence of effective atrial contraction. This leads to the absence of a wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP), as a wave is generated by atrial contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent p wave: While it is true that atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of P waves on the ECG, the question specifically asks about the JVP finding, not the ECG finding.

 

Option C. Cannon a wave: Cannon a waves are typically seen in conditions where there is atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block. They are not associated with atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Raised JVP with normal waveform: Raised JVP can occur in various conditions, but the presence of a normal waveform would not be consistent with atrial fibrillation, where the a wave is absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In atrial fibrillation, the jugular venous pulse (JVP) typically shows an absent a wave due to the lack of coordinated atrial contraction.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. Blood investigations reveal total leucocyte count to be >50,000 cells/L. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

 

Neonate with complaints of paroxysm of cough followed by apnea and leucocytosis (>50,000 cells/ L) points to diagnosis of pertussis, for which DOC is Macrolides, i.e., Azithromycin.

 

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

 

A well appearing young child begins to choke, gasp and flail the extremities with face reddened. Apnea and cyanosis may follow the coughing.

 

 

Infants < 3 months do not display the classic stages of whooping cough. Catarrhal phase is usually unnoticed.

 

Treatment – Macrolides

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is not effective against Bordetella pertussis and is not used for the treatment of pertussis.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is an alternative treatment for pertussis in patients who cannot tolerate macrolides but is not the first-line therapy.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: This antibiotic is not typically used for the treatment of pertussis and is not considered the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants presenting with pertussis (whooping cough), characterized by paroxysmal cough and elevated leukocyte count, the drug of choice is azithromycin.

questions.text: A patient was treated with repeated doses of IV anti-emetic for severe vomiting. The patient now does not have vomiting but developed abnormal movements. What is the most appropriate treatment? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Benzhexol

 

The patient likely received intravenous metoclopramide, a common anti-emetic, which can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as dystonia. Dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, leading to repetitive movements or abnormal postures. This condition can be painful and distressing.

 

The treatment of choice for drug-induced dystonia is an anticholinergic medication. Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic drug that can effectively relieve dystonic reactions by blocking acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system, thereby restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: Hyoscine (scopolamine) is primarily used to treat motion sickness and postoperative nausea. It is not effective for treating dystonia induced by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option C. Levodopa: Levodopa is used to treat Parkinson's disease by increasing dopamine levels in the brain. It is not appropriate for treating acute dystonic reactions caused by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option D. Cyproheptadine: Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with antiserotonergic and anticholinergic properties. While it can be used for some dystonic reactions, it is not the first-line treatment in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who develop dystonic reactions after receiving anti-emetic medications like metoclopramide, the most appropriate treatment is an anticholinergic drug such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl). This helps alleviate the abnormal movements by restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the central nervous system.

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyanide

 

Explanation:


Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.

 

Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

 

Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: The membrane covering an omphalocele is primarily formed by which of the following embryonic structures? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amnion

 

An omphalocele is a congenital defect in which the intestines or other abdominal organs protrude outside of the body through the umbilical ring but are covered by a protective membrane. This membrane consists of multiple layers:

 

  • Inner Layer: The inner layer of the covering is the peritoneum, which lines the abdominal cavity.
  • Middle Layer: Wharton’s jelly, a gelatinous substance, is located between the peritoneum and the outer covering.
  • Outer Layer: The outermost layer of the covering is derived from the amnion, which is part of the fetal membrane surrounding the developing fetus.

 

Thus, the amnion forms the outermost layer covering the omphalocele, providing protection to the protruding organs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm: The endoderm is the innermost germ layer that gives rise to internal structures like the lining of the gastrointestinal tract, not the covering of an omphalocele.

 

Option B. Mesoderm: The mesoderm forms muscles, bones, and connective tissues but does not specifically contribute to the external covering of an omphalocele.

 

Option C. Chorion: The chorion is another fetal membrane that participates in placental formation but does not directly form the covering of the omphalocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The outer covering of an omphalocele is derived from the amnion, with the peritoneum lining the inner surface and Wharton’s jelly situated between the peritoenum and outer covering.

questions.text: Patient came with fever and chills. Peripheral smear shown in the image. Choose the pathogen: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Plasmodium falciparum is identified in the peripheral smear by the presence of multiple rings within a single red blood cell (RBC) and the characteristic headphone-like structure known as the accolé form or appliqué form. In the provided image, multiple rings are visible in some RBCs, and a distinctive headphone-like structure can be observed, which are hallmarks of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium vivax: This species typically shows a single ring per RBC and can form larger, amoeboid shapes in the late trophozoite stage, which are not seen in this image.

 

Option C. Plasmodium ovale: This species also shows a single ring per RBC and is often characterized by an oval shape of the infected RBC and ragged cell edges, none of which are visible in the provided image.

 

Option D. Plasmodium malariae: This species shows a band form of the trophozoite across the RBC, which is not present in the image. It also typically has fewer merozoites in the schizont stage compared to Plasmodium falciparum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmodium falciparum can be distinguished by the presence of multiple rings in a single RBC and the characteristic headphone-like accolé form.

questions.text: A patient has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Identify the structure as marked? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic artery

 

The image provided shows an intraoperative view during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, focusing on the Calot's triangle. This area is critical for identifying key anatomical structures to safely remove the gallbladder.

 

Calot's triangle is bordered by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior border of the liver. The "critical view of safety" is a surgical technique used to clearly identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct before clipping and cutting them.

 

In the image, the marked structure is the inner one, closer to the liver. This inner structure is the cystic artery. The outer structure, which is away from the liver and entering the gallbladder, is the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic duct: The cystic duct is the tube that connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. In the image, it is the outer structure marked CD, which is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option C. Right hepatic artery: This artery supplies blood to the right lobe of the liver and is not typically involved in the structures identified within Calot's triangle during a cholecystectomy.

 

Option D. Hepatic duct: The hepatic duct is part of the biliary duct system, joining with the cystic duct to form the common bile duct. It is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is crucial to identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct within Calot's triangle to prevent injury to the biliary structures and ensure a safe surgical procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.

 

Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.

 

Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancoast tumor

 

Pancoast tumors, also known as superior sulcus tumors, are a type of lung cancer located at the apex (top) of the lung. These tumors are particularly associated with several key clinical features and findings, especially in chronic smokers:

 

  1. Upper chest discomfort: This is a common symptom of a Pancoast tumor due to the tumor's location at the apex of the lung.
  2. Drooping of an eyelid (ptosis): This is part of Horner's syndrome, which occurs due to compression of the sympathetic nerves by the tumor. Horner's syndrome typically includes ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face.
  3. Pain radiating to the upper arm and tingling sensation: These symptoms suggest involvement of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the arm and hand. Pancoast tumors often invade or compress these nerves, leading to referred pain and sensory disturbances in the arm and hand.
  4. Chest X-ray findings: The provided chest X-ray shows a mass at the apex of the lung, which is characteristic of a Pancoast tumor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper lobe pneumonia: While upper lobe pneumonia can cause chest discomfort and possibly pain, it is not associated with Horner's syndrome or brachial plexus involvement. The X-ray findings would also typically show consolidation rather than a mass.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava obstruction: This condition can cause swelling and discoloration of the face, neck, and upper extremities due to impaired blood flow. However, it does not explain the specific nerve-related symptoms like Horner's syndrome or tingling in the digits.

 

Option D. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls that develop in pre-existing lung cavities, usually in patients with a history of tuberculosis or other lung diseases. They do not typically present with the neurological symptoms seen in this case, nor do they commonly cause Horner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors, or superior sulcus tumors, are associated with upper chest discomfort, Horner's syndrome, and neurological symptoms in the arm due to their apical location and propensity to invade local structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

 

The classical presentation is described as the 6 P's of congenital hypothyroidism: pot-belly, pale, puffy-faced child with protruding umbilicus, protuberant tongue, and poor brain development and persistent opening of posterior fontanelle, prolong jaundice & hypotonia.

 

The given laboratory finding of increased thyroid-stimulating hormone level in an 8-day-old baby is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Radiotracer uptake with technetium will be the next investigation in this condition to confirm the presence of the thyroid gland.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine iodine excretion: This test measures the iodine content in urine and is typically used to assess iodine deficiency in populations rather than diagnosing congenital hypothyroidism in an individual.

 

Option B. Serum thyroid receptor antibody: This test is more relevant in diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases such as Graves' disease rather than congenital hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Perchlorate secretion test: This test is used to identify a defect in thyroid hormone synthesis, particularly in conditions like thyroid dyshormonogenesis, but it is not the first-line investigation for a neonate with high TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of cervical erosion and spotting since 2 months. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  LBC + HPV + cervical biopsy


The patient is a 45-year-old woman presenting with cervical erosion and spotting, which raises a concern for potential cervical cancer. In such cases, the next best step involves a comprehensive approach to screen for cervical cancer:

 

  1. Liquid-based cytology (LBC): This test is used to detect abnormal cells in the cervix.
  2. HPV testing: This helps identify high-risk human papillomavirus strains that are associated with cervical cancer.
  3. Cervical biopsy: If any abnormalities are found on cytology or HPV testing, a cervical biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

 

Performing all three tests together provides a thorough evaluation, as cervical cancer screening is essential in women presenting with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pap smear + HCV: While a Pap smear is appropriate for screening, HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) testing is unrelated to the current presentation of cervical symptoms.

 

Option C. Pap smear + HBV: Similar to option B, the Pap smear is correct, but testing for HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) does not address the concern for cervical cancer.

 

Option D. VDRL + HBV: VDRL is used for syphilis screening and is not relevant to cervical erosion and spotting, nor is HBV testing in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


For a patient with cervical erosion and spotting, the best approach is to screen for cervical cancer with LBC, HPV testing, and a cervical biopsy if indicated.

questions.text: In a study involving a population, where the mean value is 200, if the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 180-220

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD →Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD →Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD →Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

So, 68% population will cover, Mean ± 1SD.

Mean = 200

Standard Deviation = 20

 

68% population will lie between = 200 ± 20 = 180 - 220

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 32-year-old healthcare worker presents with fatigue, low-grade fever, and mild right upper quadrant discomfort for the past 2 weeks. He reports a needlestick injury 3 months ago while drawing blood from a patient with unknown hepatitis status. Physical examination reveals mild icterus and tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show elevated ALT and AST levels. Serological testing shows the presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc. What does the presence of IgM anti-HBc indicate? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute infection

 

IgM anti-HBc indicates acute hepatitis B infection. The presence of IgM antibodies generally indicates recent or ongoing infection in any disease, and hepatitis B is no exception. When combined with elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST) and HBsAg, this pattern is diagnostic of acute hepatitis B infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carrier: Carriers typically have HBsAg but negative IgM anti-HBc.

 

Option B. Chronic infection: Chronic infection is characterized by HBsAg persistence and IgG (not IgM) anti-HBc.

 

Option D. Supercarrier: This is not a standard medical term in hepatitis B infection classification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgM anti-HBc is the key serological marker for diagnosing acute hepatitis B infection, especially when accompanied by HBsAg and elevated liver enzymes.

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings located deep within the skin and other tissues. They are highly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them particularly adept at detecting fast vibrations. These receptors are crucial for perceiving textures and fine details through vibration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ruffini - Fine touch: This is incorrect because Ruffini endings are mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch, not fine touch. They are deeper in the skin and contribute to the sensation of skin deformation, which is associated with stretch rather than fine touch.

 

Option C. Meissner - Stretch: This is incorrect because Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch, not stretch. They are located near the surface of the skin and are sensitive to changes in texture and slow vibrations.

 

Option D. Merkel - Slow vibration: This is incorrect because Merkel cells are associated with fine touch and two-point discrimination, not slow vibrations. They are particularly sensitive to edges, points, and textures, which aids in tasks like reading Braille.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: A Child presents with asymmetric crying face and inability to close the left eye as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve palsy

 

The clinical features shown in the image are characteristic of facial nerve (CN VII) palsy, also known as Bell's palsy.

 

Important features: 

 

  • Inability to close the eye (loss of orbicularis oculi function) 
  • Asymmetry of face 
  • Deviation of mouth to the normal side 
  • Loss of wrinkling and nasolabial fold on affected side This is due to damage to the facial nerve which supplies all muscles of facial expression including orbicularis oculi, buccinator, and other facial muscles.
  • The facial nerve emerges at the pontomedullary junction and exits through the stylomastoid foramen.
  • Facial nerve palsy can be idiopathic (Bell’s palsy) or secondary to infections (e.g., Herpes simplex, Ramsay Hunt syndrome), trauma, tumors, or stroke.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve palsy: 

 

  • Causes ptosis, an enlarged pupil, and an eye deviated "down and out" due to loss of extraocular muscle function.

 

Option C. Orbicularis oculi palsy:

 

  • This muscle is supplied by cranial nerve VII (facial nerve).
  • While paralysis of orbicularis oculi can cause incomplete eyelid closure, it does not affect other facial muscles as seen in facial nerve palsy.

 

Option D. Erb’s palsy

 

  • A brachial plexus injury (C5-C6), often seen in newborns after traumatic delivery.
  • Characterized by "waiter's tip" deformity (adducted, internally rotated arm with extended elbow and flexed wrist).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bell’s palsy - Loss of Wrinkling, Wide palpebral fissure, Whistling loss, loss of nasolabial fold and drooling of saliva

questions.text: During laparoscopic surgery, which vessels are most prone to injury while inserting trocars? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both B and C (Inferior Epigastric Artery & Superior Epigastric Artery)

 

Explanation:

 

During laparoscopic surgery, trocars are inserted through the abdominal wall, and the most commonly injured vessels are epigastric arteries, specifically:

 

  1. Inferior Epigastric Artery (IEA) → Runs posterior to the rectus abdominis, arising from the external iliac artery. It is commonly injured during trocar placement at the lateral ports (midclavicular line or lateral to rectus muscle).
  2. Superior Epigastric Artery (SEA) → Arises from the internal thoracic artery, supplying the upper abdominal wall. It is less commonly injured but still at risk in upper trocar insertions near the midline.

 

Risk factors 

 

  • Inferior epigastric artery (IEA) runs lateral to the rectus muscle.
  • Most laparoscopic trocars are placed in the periumbilical region and lateral ports, near IEA’s path.
  • Injury to these vessels can lead to significant bleeding or hematoma formation, especially retroperitoneal hematoma.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Abdominal Aorta → Incorrect

 

  • The aorta is a retroperitoneal structure, located deep in the abdomen.
  • It is not commonly injured during standard trocar placement unless there is misplacement of a Veress needle or excessive force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior and Superior Epigastric Arteries are the most commonly injured vessels during laparoscopic trocar insertion. Using transillumination and proper trocar placement can prevent vascular injury.



Management of Epigastric Artery Injury:

 

  1. Preventive Measure:
    • Use transillumination to identify epigastric vessels before inserting trocars.
    • Place lateral trocars either lateral or medial to epigastric artery path.
  2. If Injury Occurs:
    • Immediate control using electrocautery or direct pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is a hexanucleotide repeat disorder? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frontotemporal dementia

 

Frontotemporal dementia, specifically the form associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (FTD-ALS complex), is caused by a hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9ORF72 gene. This expansion consists of GGGGCC (G4C2) repeats. It's one of the few known hexanucleotide repeat disorders and is a significant cause of both frontotemporal dementia and ALS.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fragile X Syndrome: Incorrect. This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CGG repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene.

 

Option C. Myotonic dystrophy: Incorrect. There are two types of myotonic dystrophy. Type 1 is a trinucleotide (CTG) repeat disorder, while type 2 is a tetranucleotide (CCTG) repeat disorder.

 

Option D. Huntington disease: Incorrect. This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CAG repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene, resulting in an expanded polyglutamine tract.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

The chloride level of sweat is evaluated in cystic fibrosis.

 

CYSTIC FIBROSIS

 

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Mutation in chromosome no. 7
  • Primary defect: CFTR gene [Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene on chromosome 7q31.2]
  • Other defects: Chloride channels, Potassium channels, Epithelial sodium channels

 

 

  • Sweat ducts normally absorb sodium from lumen which decreases in CF causing salty sweat.
  • Excessive loss of salt in the sweat is there. Other ducts are obstructed.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

Hallmark of cystic fibrosis –

 

High sodium and chloride levels Sweat chloride level is >60mEq/L in 2 occasions Airways, pancreas & GIT - Normally sodium uptake is there from luminal fluid but in CF there is increase of sodium and water uptake from lumen causing thick, viscid secretions.

 

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Phenylketonuria occurs due to absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme, leading to phenylketonuria. Diagnosis is made by Ferric chloride test, Guthrie test.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of the tissue enzyme glucocerebrosidase that splits glucose from glucosylceramide, resulting in accumulation of the latter in cells of the reticuloendothelial system. Diagnosis is made by measuring glucocerebrosidase levels in leukocytes or skin fibroblasts. Serum chitotriosidase levels are elevated.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta causes defective type-1 collagen. Presents with a triad of blue sclera, Fragile bones, Early deafness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lumbricals and interossei

 

  • The Lumbricals (+ interossei) paralysis causes claw hand (MCP hyperextension and IP joint flexion).

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hyperextension of the MCP joint and flexion of the IP joint is seen in the claw hand deformity due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand i.e., the lumbricals and the interossei.

questions.text: Desert rheumatism is caused by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coccidioides immitis


Desert rheumatism, also known as Valley fever or California fever, is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis. This fungus is commonly found in desert regions, such as the southwestern United States, including California and Arizona. The disease is contracted by inhaling airborne fungal spores, which can cause symptoms ranging from mild flu-like conditions to severe pulmonary or disseminated infections. The mnemonic "Desert, Valley, Cali" helps remember the association with desert rheumatism, Valley fever, and California fever, all linked to Coccidioides immitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: This condition is caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, which is commonly found in bird and bat droppings, particularly in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. It does not cause desert rheumatism.

 

Option C. Mucormycosis: This is an infection caused by molds from the Mucorales order, which typically affects immunocompromised individuals. It is not associated with desert rheumatism.

 

Option D. Paracoccidioidomycosis: This disease is caused by the fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and occurs predominantly in South America. It is unrelated to desert rheumatism.

 

Educational Objective:


Desert rheumatism (Valley fever or California fever) is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis.

questions.text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 37 degrees C

 

Frostbite should be managed with rapid and complete thawing using a circulating water bath maintained between 37°C and 40°C. This temperature range is optimal to reverse vascular stasis and initiate reperfusion without causing thermal injury.

 

Thawing at this range is typically performed for 30 to 60 minutes and should be done only when the possibility of refreezing is excluded. Higher temperatures like 42°C are not recommended and may worsen tissue injury.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 42°C: Too hot. It exceeds the upper recommended limit and can risk thermal damage to already compromised tissue.

 

Option C. 32°C: Insufficient to produce effective rewarming. Rewarming would be slow and incomplete.

 

Option D. 30°C: Ineffective. Tissue remains partially frozen and vulnerable to re-freezing injury.

 

Educational Objective:


Frostbite should be rewarmed in circulating water at 37–40°C for 30–60 minutes, avoiding hot air or dry heat.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a history of chronic sun exposure presented with bilateral brownish pigmentation over the face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melasma

 

Melasma is characterized by bilateral, symmetrical brownish pigmentation, primarily on the face, commonly seen in pregnant women or individuals with chronic sun exposure. In this case, the patient's history of pregnancy and chronic sun exposure, along with the image showing patchy pigmentation, strongly suggests melasma. Melasma in pregnant women is often referred to as chloasma or the "mask of pregnancy." It is associated with hormonal changes and UV exposure. Additionally, melasma is often linked to thyroid disorders.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is typically characterized by the ABCDE features: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter greater than 6mm, and Evolution of the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Suntan: A suntan results in diffuse pigmentation over sun-exposed areas, usually with an initial red phase. The pigmentation in a suntan is not patchy as seen in the image provided but rather more uniform. Therefore, suntan is not the correct diagnosis.

 

 

Option D. Nevus of OTA: This condition presents with unilateral blue or grey pigmentation, often involving the sclera and skin on the face. The absence of these characteristic features and the presence of bilateral brown pigmentation make Nevus of OTA an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melasma, especially in pregnant women, presents as bilateral, symmetrical brownish patches on the face, often linked to sun exposure and hormonal changes.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 
The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is characterized by hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction of the gastric outlet. Clinically, it often presents in infants around 3-6 weeks old with symptoms such as projectile vomiting (non-bilious), an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, and visible peristalsis. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis by showing a thickened pyloric muscle with measurements typically around 4 mm in thickness and 16 mm in length, which are diagnostic for CHPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is characterized by the telescoping of one segment of the intestine into another, leading to symptoms like colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and “red currant jelly” stools (due to blood and mucus). It commonly presents with intermittent, severe abdominal pain and is typically not associated with a palpable olive-shaped mass or recurrent vomiting alone.

 

Option C. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital abnormality that results from an incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct. It may present with painless rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, or signs of intestinal obstruction. The appearance on imaging is different, and it is not associated with the olive-shaped mass or the characteristic pyloric muscle thickening seen in CHPS.

 

Educational Objective:


CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: Which ion is most responsible for the resting membrane potential (RMP): (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of a cell is primarily determined by the distribution of ions across the cell membrane and the relative permeability of the membrane to those ions. Potassium ions (K+) play the most significant role in establishing the RMP. This is because the cell membrane is more permeable to K+ ions compared to other ions, and there is a higher concentration of K+ inside the cell than outside.

 

The movement of K+ out of the cell down its concentration gradient leads to a negative charge inside the cell relative to the outside. This difference in charge across the membrane is what we refer to as the RMP. Other ions, such as sodium (Na+), calcium (Ca2+), and chloride (Cl-), have some influence, but their impact is much less compared to K+.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca2+: Calcium ions have a much smaller role in setting the RMP. They are more involved in processes like muscle contraction and neurotransmitter release rather than in establishing the RMP.

 

Option C. Na+: Sodium ions have a minimal direct role in determining the RMP under normal conditions because the cell membrane is much less permeable to Na+ at rest compared to K+. The Na+/K+ pump helps maintain the gradient of Na+ and K+, but Na+ itself does not significantly influence the RMP.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions can influence the RMP, but their effect is secondary to that of K+. Since the membrane is more permeable to K+, the RMP is predominantly a result of K+ distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by the concentration gradient of potassium ions (K+) across the cell membrane and the membrane's permeability to K+.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Vitamin D The image show Bowing of the legs, a condition known as bowlegs or genu varum, is commonly associated with Vitamin D deficiency, especially in children. Vitamin D plays a crucial role in the regulation of calcium and phosphorus, essential minerals for bone health. Deficiency of Vitamin D can lead to improper mineralization of bones, resulting in deformities such as bowing of the legs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of the legs. However, severe vitamin A deficiency cause night blindness and other eye menifestations.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Vitamin B3 deficiency can cause pellagra, which involves skin, gastrointestinal, and neurological symptoms. It is not directly linked to bowing of the legs.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Vitamin B1 deficiency can lead to beriberi, a condition that primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. It is not a common cause of bowing of the legs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in Iron overdose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BAL

 

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite), also known as Dimercaprol, is contraindicated in cases of iron overdose. This is because BAL forms toxic complexes with iron, which can worsen the patient’s condition. BAL is typically used as a chelating agent for heavy metals like arsenic, mercury (inorganic), and lead, but it is specifically contraindicated in iron, cadmium, selenium, and organic mercury poisoning due to the risk of severe toxicity.

 

The correct treatment for iron overdose is Desferrioxamine, which specifically binds to iron, forming a stable complex that is then excreted from the body. Desferrioxamine is the treatment of choice in acute iron poisoning due to its specific chelation properties for iron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desferrioxamine: This is the correct treatment for iron overdose as it binds iron effectively and facilitates its excretion. It is not contraindicated; rather, it is the primary treatment option.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): EDTA is not commonly used for iron overdose, as its primary use is in chelating lead and other heavy metals. While it is not the preferred treatment for iron poisoning, it is not specifically contraindicated as BAL is.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because Desferrioxamine is actually the treatment of choice for iron overdose, and EDTA can be used in some cases if Desferrioxamine is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAL is contraindicated in iron overdose due to its potential to form harmful complexes, making Desferrioxamine the preferred treatment in such cases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with motor traffic accident with BP 90/60mm Hg. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechia were seen. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. eFAST

 

Explanation:

 

The next step in the evaluation of a trauma patient with the given findings is the Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST). This non-invasive imaging technique is crucial for rapidly identifying free fluid and organ injuries in the abdomen, as well as potential pneumothorax or hemothorax, which are critical in trauma cases. eFAST is used to quickly assess both stable and unstable patients following blunt abdominal trauma, providing immediate information that can dictate further management steps.

 

Details:

 

eFAST Role: This ultrasound examination checks for free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid and can evaluate the integrity of the pleural spaces.

 

Stability: Despite the patient's low blood pressure, he is neurologically intact (GCS 15/15) and responsive, which allows for an ultrasound examination before more invasive procedures are considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exploratory laparotomy: Generally reserved for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability after eFAST or when eFAST is positive for intra-abdominal injury needing surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Intubation: Might be necessary if respiratory status worsens or if advanced airway management is required, but the patient’s current stable neurological status does not immediately warrant this.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan): Used after eFAST if the patient remains hemodynamically stable and further detailed evaluation of internal injuries is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania tropica

 

 

Difference between Leishmania tropica and donovani is that tropica do not invade organs. It causes cutaneous leishmaniasis otherwise called as Delhi boil, Aleppo boil.

 

Following image shows an ulcer surrounded by erythema

 

 

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

 

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

 

 

LIFE CYCLE IS GIVEN OF FILARIA:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia causes babesiosis, a tick-borne disease, presents as a malaria-like illness with fever, chills, and hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cause diseases like African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) and American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease), presents with different clinical features, such as fever, swollen lymph nodes, and neurological symptoms in African trypanosomiasis while in Chagas disease, fever and swelling at the infection site, and cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Histoplasma (dimorphic fungus) causes histoplasmosis. Mostly affects the lungs and then can disseminate to other organs in immunocompromised individuals. Presents variably, but it does not typically cause an ulcer with erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

choices.text: SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with pedal edema, abdominal distension, and distended neck veins. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following will be seen? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of right heart failure, such as pedal edema, abdominal distension, and distended neck veins. The chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with maintained contours, suggesting a "money bag" heart appearance characteristic of pericardial effusion. The patient likely has a history of tuberculosis and might have developed constrictive pericarditis, then pericardial effusion and which progressed to tamponade.

 

Additionally, the combination of jugular venous distension and hypotension points towards cardiac tamponade. Pulsus paradoxus, a significant fall in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, is a hallmark of cardiac tamponade. In this case, the systolic BP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration indicates pulsus paradoxus, confirming tamponade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus bisferians: This is typically seen in conditions like severe aortic regurgitation, a combination of aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation, or hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). These conditions do not match the clinical presentation and X-ray findings of the patient.

 

Option C. Kussmaul breathing: This type of deep and labored breathing is associated with severe metabolic acidosis, such as diabetic ketoacidosis. It is not related to the clinical scenario of pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade.

 

Option D. Fine crepitations: Fine crepitations are a sign of pulmonary congestion often seen in left ventricular failure. In the case of cardiac tamponade, there is no pulmonary congestion as the blood is not effectively moving into the pulmonary circulation, thus crepitations would not be present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by pulsus paradoxus, which is a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, often exceeding 10 mm Hg

questions.text: A patient presented with severe back ache and the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture present. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Chance fracture

 

The image presented shows a spine injury, and based on the clinical scenario (a patient presenting after an RTA or road traffic accident), the fracture pattern described fits that of a Chance fracture. A Chance fracture, also known as a flexion-distraction injury or seatbelt fracture, typically occurs due to high-force flexion injuries, such as in a car accident where a seatbelt restrains the lower body while the upper body moves forward. This type of fracture involves a horizontal break extending through all three spinal columns (anterior, middle, and posterior)

 

The Chance fracture goes from anterior to posterior, involving all three columns, which is a hallmark feature of this injury. The description matches the flexion-distraction mechanism associated with this fracture.

 

Additional Information

 

Common spine fractures:

 

  1. Jefferson fracture:
    • Also called a ring fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra).
    • Mnemonic: JAT.
  2. Hangman's fracture:
    • Fracture through the interarticularis of the C2 vertebra, causing a slip of C2 over C3 (spondylolisthesis).
    • Mnemonic: H2 (Hangman’s fracture, C2 vertebra).
  3. Whiplash injury:
    • Occurs due to hyperextension followed by flexion (e.g., in a high-speed vehicle accident where the vehicle suddenly stops).
    • Resembles the motion of a whiplash.
  4. Wedge fracture:
    • The anterior height of the vertebral body is lowered while the posterior height remains normal.
  5. Burst fracture:
    • Involves damage to the anterior, middle, and posterior columns of the vertebra.
    • The vertebral body is damaged, involving both the anterior and middle columns.
    • Atlas (Jefferson) fracture is also considered a burst fracture.
  6. Chance Fracture:
    • The force moves from anterior to posterior, going all the way to the spinous process.
    • Involves flexion of the body with a distraction force.
    • Also known as jackknife or seatbelt fracture.
  7. Hinge fracture: A fracture where the skull base is divided into two halves: anterior and posterior.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burst fracture: A burst fracture involves damage to the anterior and middle columns of the vertebra, with fragments spreading outwards. While a burst fracture may result from high-energy trauma, the image and clinical description provided in this question are more characteristic of a Chance fracture. The distribution of injury in a burst fracture does not typically extend through all three columns.

 

Option C. Compression fracture: Compression fractures generally affect the anterior part of the vertebra, causing a wedge-shaped deformity, but they do not involve the middle and posterior columns like the Chance fracture. These fractures are often seen in patients with osteoporosis rather than as a result of high-energy trauma.

 

Option D. Fracture of spinous process: A fracture of the spinous process (such as a Clay-shoveler's fracture) usually involves a break in the posterior part of the vertebra only and does not involve the anterior or middle columns. This type of fracture typically occurs from direct trauma or forceful flexion but doesn't match the findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in ADHD is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reboxetine

  

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) primarily used as an antidepressant. It selectively inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine, enhancing its concentration in the synaptic cleft, which is beneficial in treating ADHD symptoms. Although it is not commonly used as a first-line treatment for ADHD, it can be prescribed off-label in certain cases due to its mechanism of action targeting norepinephrine, which plays a significant role in attention and impulse control.

 

Note – Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), used in treating ADHD, but not mentioned in option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Modafinil: Modafinil is a stimulant that promotes wakefulness and is used primarily for conditions like narcolepsy and sleep disorders. It is not a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and works mainly by influencing dopamine pathways, making it unsuitable as an answer.

 

Option C. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is a central nervous system stimulant commonly used to treat ADHD, but it works primarily by inhibiting the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine rather than selectively targeting norepinephrine alone.

 

Option D. Guanfacine: Guanfacine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of ADHD. It does not inhibit norepinephrine reuptake but instead works by stimulating alpha-2 receptors, which reduces sympathetic nerve impulses, leading to a calming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for ADHD, distinct from other ADHD medications that target both norepinephrine and dopamine or act on other neurotransmitter systems.

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation and presents with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. On examination, fetal movements are normal, fetal parts not easily felt and muffled fetal heartbeat is heard. Symphysis fundal height came out to be 41 cm.
