Per abdomen examination reveals tense abdomen but not tender. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyhydramnios

 

The given scenario of 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

 

Polyhydramnios

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placenta: Abruption Placenta presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.

 

Option B. Hydrocephalus of fetus: Hydrocephalus of the fetus leads to increased head circumference in the fetus, which may cause an increased symphysis fundal height but unlikely to cause breathlessness and abdominal distension to this extent.

 

Option D. Fetal-maternal ascites: Patients of Fetal-maternal ascites commonly present with edema, proteinuria, hypertension, elevated liver enzymes and headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, it most likely points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and episodes of jaundice. Ultrasound shows multiple pigmented gallstones in the gallbladder. Laboratory tests reveal elevated bilirubin levels. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows abnormal hemoglobin patterns. The patient has a history of beta-thalassemia minor. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with the formation of pigmented gallstones? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta-thalassemia minor

 

Beta-thalassemia minor (also called beta-thalassemia trait) is the least likely cause of pigmented gallstones among the options because it is typically asymptomatic and represents an incidental diagnosis. Patients with beta-thalassemia minor usually have mild or no hemolysis, and therefore do not develop the excessive bilirubin production that leads to pigmented gallstone formation. They generally have minimal symptoms, with only mild anemia that does not require treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemoglobin D (HbD) Punjab: Incorrect. While Hemoglobin D Punjab by itself may cause minimal symptoms, it can lead to increased hemolysis when co-existing with other hemoglobinopathies like thalassemia or sickle cell disease. This hemolysis can result in increased bilirubin production and subsequent pigmented gallstone formation.

 

Option C. G6PD deficiency: Incorrect. G6PD deficiency causes episodes of acute hemolysis typically triggered by certain drugs, infections, or foods like fava beans. During these hemolytic episodes, there is increased bilirubin production that can contribute to pigmented gallstone formation over time.

 

Option D. Sickle cell disease: Incorrect. Sickle cell disease is strongly associated with pigmented gallstone formation due to chronic hemolysis. The sickle hemoglobin causes red blood cells to become rigid and break down prematurely, resulting in increased bilirubin production. This makes sickle cell disease one of the most common causes of pigmented gallstones among hemoglobinopathies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-thalassemia minor (trait) is typically asymptomatic and not associated with significant hemolysis or pigmented gallstone formation, in contrast to other hemoglobinopathies like sickle cell disease that cause chronic hemolysis and increased bilirubin production.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl born out of non-consanguineous marriage presented with rachitic changes in limbs since 1½ years of age for which she has received multiple courses of vitamin D. Investigations showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

The clinical scenario of a child with resistant rickets and the following laboratory findings—normal serum calcium, normal parathyroid hormone, decreased serum phosphate, increased alkaline phosphatase, decreased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, increased urinary phosphate, decreased urinary calcium, and normal ABG and serum creatinine—is highly suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Hypophosphatemic Rickets: This condition is characterized by low serum phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, leading to rickets despite normal or elevated levels of vitamin D. It is often caused by mutations affecting phosphate-regulating genes like PHEX.
  • Laboratory Findings: The hallmark of this condition includes low serum phosphate, high alkaline phosphatase, normal serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D dependent rickets: This would typically show low calcium and elevated parathyroid hormone levels due to impaired vitamin D metabolism or action. Serum phosphate may also be low, but the distinguishing factor is the response to vitamin D therapy, which is absent in hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition usually presents with low calcium and high phosphate levels due to insufficient parathyroid hormone. The given case has normal calcium and low phosphate, making hypoparathyroidism unlikely.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: This would typically show elevated serum creatinine along with abnormalities in calcium and phosphate metabolism. The normal creatinine level in this patient rules out chronic renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate, normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, commonly due to PHEX gene mutations.
